title: Electric potential - P1 and P3 if charge q moves

content.question: Two charged particles, one of charge <math alttext="negative q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>q</mi></mpadded></math> and one of charge <math alttext="positive q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi></mpadded></math>, are located on the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis of a coordinate system, as shown in the figure. Points <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="P sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are on the axis at <math alttext="x equals 1 centimeter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> and <math alttext="x equals 3 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>, respectively. The particle of charge <math alttext="positive q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi></mpadded></math> is then moved from <math alttext="x equals 4 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> to <math alttext="x equals 2 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>. What happens to the electric potentials <math alttext="V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> at points <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="P sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, respectively, when the positive particle is moved?

choices.label: <math alttext="V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> becomes higher and <math alttext="V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> becomes lower.

<math alttext="V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> becomes higher and <math alttext="V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> stays the same.

<math alttext="V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> becomes lower and <math alttext="V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> becomes lower.

<math alttext="V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> becomes lower and <math alttext="V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> stays the same.

content.answer: <math alttext="V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> becomes higher and <math alttext="V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> stays the same.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
